pages.title: About
pages.content:
Hello, I'm Alex

A designer who believes great design is invisible — until it moves you.

With over 10 years of experience in digital design, I've had the privilege of working with startups, agencies, and Fortune 500 companies to create experiences that resonate. My journey began with a fascination for the intersection of art and technology, and that curiosity continues to drive every project I take on.

My Story

I graduated from the Royal College of Art with a Master's in Visual Communication, where I first fell in love with the power of systematic design thinking. After spending my early career at Pentagram and later leading the design team at a Series B startup, I went independent in 2020 to pursue the kind of work that truly excites me — projects at the boundary of brand, product, and motion.

My approach is rooted in research, storytelling, and meticulous craft. I believe every pixel should earn its place. Whether I'm building a complete brand system, designing an app from scratch, or crafting a 15-second motion piece, the process always starts with understanding people — their goals, frustrations, and aspirations.

When I'm not designing, you'll find me experimenting with generative art, mentoring junior designers at ADPList, or exploring the latest exhibition at the Barbican. I'm a firm believer that creativity thrives on diverse inputs.

Core Skills

🎨

UI/UX Design

User-centered interfaces that are both beautiful and functional

✦

Branding

Complete brand identities that tell a compelling story

▶

Motion Design

Engaging animations and micro-interactions that delight

◆

Immersive 3D visuals and product renders that captivate

🎓 Education

pages.title: Services
pages.content:
What I Offer

Design services tailored to your needs

Every engagement is unique. Here's a starting point — we'll shape the scope together based on your goals, timeline, and budget.

✦

Brand Identity

From $3,000

A comprehensive brand identity that captures your essence and sets you apart. From strategy to execution, I build brands with lasting impact — rooted in research, refined through iteration.

Deliverables

  • ✓ Brand strategy & positioning
  • ✓ Logo design & symbol system
  • ✓ Color palette & typography
  • ✓ Brand guidelines document
  • ✓ Business card & stationery

⏱ Timeline: 3–5 weeks

◈

Web Design

From $5,000

Beautiful, conversion-focused websites that work as hard as they look. I design responsive experiences from landing pages to full marketing sites — always performance-first.

Deliverables

  • ✓ UX research & wireframes
  • ✓ Full responsive design (Figma)
  • ✓ Design system & components
  • ✓ Interaction specifications
  • ✓ Developer handoff

⏱ Timeline: 4–8 weeks

▣

App UI/UX

From $8,000

End-to-end product design for iOS, Android, or cross-platform apps. I map user journeys, prototype interactions, and deliver production-ready interfaces that your users will love.

Deliverables

  • ✓ User research & personas
  • ✓ Information architecture
  • ✓ Interactive prototype
  • ✓ Full UI design (all screens)
  • ✓ Design tokens & documentation

⏱ Timeline: 6–12 weeks

▶

Motion Design

From $2,000

From subtle UI animations to full brand reveal videos, I craft motion that adds meaning and personality. Perfect for product launches, social content, and brand storytelling.

Deliverables

  • ✓ Storyboard & concept
  • ✓ Animation (After Effects / Lottie)
  • ✓ UI micro-interactions
  • ✓ Export in all formats
  • ✓ Implementation guidance

⏱ Timeline: 1–3 weeks

Need something custom?

Every project is different. Let's chat about your specific needs and I'll put together a tailored proposal.

Get in Touch →

articles.title: Design Systems: Why Every Brand Needs One
articles.content:
If your brand lives across a website, an app, social media, email campaigns, and print — how do you keep it all consistent? The answer is a design system. It's not just a style guide or a component library; it's a single source of truth that aligns every touchpoint of your brand experience.

What exactly is a design system?

A design system is a collection of reusable components, guided by clear standards, that can be assembled to build any number of applications. Think of it as the vocabulary and grammar of your brand's visual language. It includes foundational elements — color tokens, typography scales, spacing units — alongside patterns like buttons, cards, navigation, and forms.

Why your brand can't afford to skip it

Consistency at scale. Without a system, every new page or feature is a blank canvas — which sounds creative, but usually leads to fragmentation. Design systems ensure that your checkout flow feels the same as your onboarding, no matter who designed it.

Speed. Teams working with a mature design system ship 2–3× faster. Designers stop reinventing the wheel; developers stop guessing at spacing values. Everyone references the same Figma library and the same code components.

Quality. When the foundations are solid, you spend less time fixing inconsistencies and more time solving real user problems. Accessibility, responsiveness, and interaction patterns get baked in once and propagated everywhere.

Getting started

You don't need a 500-page document. Start with an audit of what you have: screenshot every page, catalog every color, list every font weight. Identify the patterns, consolidate the variations, and document the decisions. The system will grow organically from there — just make sure it has an owner and a governance process.

A design system isn't a project with a deadline. It's a product that evolves alongside your brand.
articles.excerpt: A design system is your brand's single source of truth — learn why consistency, speed, and quality depend on building one.
articles.meta_title: Design Systems: Why Every Brand Needs One | Alex Chen
articles.meta_description: Learn why design systems are essential for brand consistency, faster shipping, and higher quality. A practical guide to getting started with your own design system.

articles.title: The Psychology of Color in UI Design
articles.content:
Color isn't decoration — it's communication. Every hue carries emotional weight, cultural context, and cognitive associations that shape how users perceive and interact with your interface. Understanding color psychology isn't optional for designers; it's foundational.

The science behind the feeling

Research in environmental psychology shows that color influences mood, attention, and decision-making within milliseconds. Blue evokes trust and calm — which is why it dominates fintech and healthcare. Red triggers urgency and excitement, making it the go-to for CTAs and error states. Green signals safety and growth, a natural fit for success messages and eco-brands.

Context changes everything

Color meaning isn't universal. White represents purity in Western cultures but mourning in parts of East Asia. Red means luck in China but danger in the US. When designing for global audiences, test your palette across cultural contexts. What feels premium in London might feel aggressive in Tokyo.

Accessibility adds another layer. Roughly 8% of men and 0.5% of women have some form of color vision deficiency. If your interface relies solely on color to convey meaning — red for error, green for success — you're excluding millions of users. Always pair color with icons, labels, or patterns.

Practical tips for your next project

Limit your palette. A primary color, a secondary accent, and a neutral scale is all most interfaces need. Every additional color adds cognitive load. Use saturation intentionally. Highly saturated colors grab attention — use them sparingly for actions and alerts. Desaturated tones work better for backgrounds and large surfaces.

Test in context. A color that looks brilliant on your Retina display might wash out on a budget Android phone. Always validate contrast ratios (WCAG AA minimum: 4.5:1) and test under different lighting conditions.

Great color choices feel invisible. They guide, reassure, and excite — without the user ever knowing why.
articles.excerpt: Color is communication — explore how hue, saturation, and cultural context shape user perception in interface design.
articles.meta_title: The Psychology of Color in UI Design | Alex Chen
articles.meta_description: How color psychology influences user behavior in UI design. Learn about emotional associations, cultural context, accessibility, and practical palette tips.

articles.title: From Sketch to Ship: My Design Process
articles.content:
People often ask me what my process looks like. The honest answer? It's messy, nonlinear, and full of dead ends — but it has a shape. Over the past decade, I've refined a framework that balances creative exploration with the discipline needed to actually ship great work.

Phase 1: Understand

Every project starts with listening. I spend the first week in discovery — stakeholder interviews, competitive audits, user research if the budget allows it. The goal isn't to form opinions yet; it's to absorb context. I'm looking for the constraints that will make the design interesting and the opportunities everyone else has missed.

Phase 2: Explore

This is where the sketchbook comes out. I'll generate 20–30 rough concepts in a day — pen on paper, no screens. Speed kills perfectionism. From those sketches, I'll identify 3–4 directions worth pursuing and bring them into Figma as low-fidelity wireframes. I present these to the client with honest assessments of trade-offs.

Phase 3: Refine

Once we've aligned on a direction, I move into high-fidelity design. This is where the magic happens — or rather, where the craft happens. Pixel-perfect layouts, typographic fine-tuning, color harmony, micro-interactions. I build everything in a structured component system so it's easy for developers to implement and easy for the brand to scale.

Phase 4: Ship

Design doesn't end at the Figma handoff. I stay involved through development — reviewing builds, catching details, adjusting animations. The gap between design and implementation is where quality goes to die, and I refuse to let that happen. Once we launch, I'll do a post-launch review to capture what worked, what didn't, and what to improve next time.

Process is a tool, not a cage. The best work happens when you know the rules well enough to break them intentionally.
articles.excerpt: A look inside my four-phase design process: understand, explore, refine, and ship — with honesty about the messy parts.
articles.meta_title: From Sketch to Ship: My Design Process | Alex Chen
articles.meta_description: Inside Alex Chen's design process: from discovery and sketching to high-fidelity design and developer handoff. A practical look at how great design ships.

articles.title: 5 Typography Trends Dominating 2026
articles.content:
Typography is having a moment. As interfaces mature and brands compete for attention in increasingly crowded digital spaces, type has become the primary vehicle for personality and hierarchy. Here are five trends shaping how we set type in 2026.

1. Variable fonts go mainstream

Variable fonts have been around since 2016, but 2026 is the year they become the default choice. With a single file offering infinite weight, width, and optical size variations, they eliminate the performance penalty of loading multiple font files. Expect to see more brands using variable fonts for fluid, responsive typography that adapts to viewport size in real time.

2. Neo-grotesque revival

Clean, neutral sans-serifs are back — but with a twist. New releases like General Sans, Switzer, and Satoshi offer the geometric clarity of Helvetica with more personality: wider apertures, subtle ink traps, and optical corrections that feel warmer on screen. They're replacing the ultra-geometric types that dominated the 2020s.

3. Kinetic type in UI

Motion is no longer reserved for hero sections and loading screens. We're seeing animated text as a core UI pattern — headings that morph between states, labels that animate on interaction, counters that roll instead of snap. Used with restraint, kinetic type adds delight and communicates state changes more naturally than static text.

4. Oversized serif headlines

Big, bold serifs are commanding hero sections everywhere. The contrast between a 120px editorial serif headline and a clean sans-serif body creates dramatic visual hierarchy. Fonts like Fraunces, Instrument Serif, and Playfair Display are seeing massive adoption — particularly in portfolio sites, editorial platforms, and luxury brands.

5. AI-assisted type pairing

Tools like Fontjoy and newer AI-powered pairing engines are changing how designers choose type combinations. Rather than relying on safe pairings from curated lists, designers are exploring unusual combinations validated by AI analysis of contrast, proportion, and rhythm. The result: more distinctive, unexpected type systems.

Typography is the voice of your interface. In 2026, that voice is variable, kinetic, and bolder than ever.
articles.excerpt: From variable fonts going mainstream to kinetic type in UI — five typography trends defining digital design in 2026.
articles.meta_description: Explore the top 5 typography trends of 2026: variable fonts, neo-grotesque revival, kinetic type, oversized serifs, and AI-assisted type pairing.
